newsitem.title: USA: New York Times names Bill Keller managing editor.
newsitem.headline: New York Times names Bill Keller managing editor.

text.p: The New York Times said Thursday that it named Bill Keller managing editor, replacing Gene Roberts, who completes a three-year tour in the position while on leave as a professor at the University of Maryland.
Keller becomes the second-highest editor at the newspaper. He will work as Roberts' deputy for an orientation period starting July 1, until Roberts leaves his position in the fall.
Keller joined the Times in 1984 as a Washington correspondant and won a Pulitzer Prize in 1989 for his coverage of the Soviet Union.
The company also named Gerald Boyd deputy managing editor for news, effective July 1. Boyd, who is currently an assistant managing editor, joined the Times in 1983 as a White House correspondant.
John Geddes, currently business and financial editor, was appointed deputy managing editor for operations, effective Sept. 1. He joined the newspaper as a business editor in 1994.
